title: What do you think when you hear someone singing badly? - Quora

response.answer_text: For me it somewhat depends on context. If I am sitting in my car at a stoplight, with the windows rolled down and happen to hear someone in another car singing badly, I tend to smile. I appreciate their passion and joy. I acknowledge that I sing in the car too sometimes, and it’s probably not good. What I really, really dislike is when people sing in a public, shared space that you can’t avoid or escape… like on a train, or a bus. Even if it is moderately good singing, sometimes its just weird and awkward and annoying. I have several co-workers who occasionally break out in song at work. Two of them sing pretty well, and I will go along with it unless the singing is really disrupting my work or focus, in which case I ask them to stop singing until I leave the area. BUT, there is another co-worker who doesn’t *sing* so much as just chant or shout out two random lines of a rap song over and over intermittently throughout the day. It is completely, utterly obnoxious. He has no tone variations. No flow. I imagine it is a bit like working with someone who has Tourette’s, but in this case he is intentionally being loud and sometimes using inappropriate language just to annoy other people. People with a disability cannot help it. This guy is really just completely inconsiderate. He knows it annoys other people, and continues to do it gleefully.

It very much so depends on the situation and what you mean by “badly”. If they’re singing a Justin Bieber song, it’s bad by default (sorry Bieber fans no personal offense intended :P) and I try to avoid it as much as possible. No high-quality voice can save that… :P On the other hand, if they’re just flat/sharp, I usually try to avoid cringing (I am apparently very sensitive to pitch, maybe from having studied music from very early on) and if it’s my brother, I just tell him he was off and then ignore it; otherwise, I just ignore it. I can blot out sounds somewhat when I’m focused on something, as indicated by when my parents get irritated that somehow I didn’t hear (not didn’t hear clearly; just completely didn’t hear) a complete sentence directed to me :P If it’s truly horrible and I can avoid it, I usually leave, listen to other music over theirs, or just deal with it if it’s not going to be for too long. If they’re singing really obnoxiously in a place I can’t avoid, I won’t confront them because I try to not make enemies with anyone, so I just deal with it and try to handle the irreversible damage to my already low sanity :P

It depends on the context. I heard someone who couldn’t sing while she sang AMAZING GRACE at the bedside of her dying mother. It was the most beautiful thing I heard. I heard a really bad youth choir sing SILENT NIGHT and it brought tears to my eyes. Mostly I analyze why they are bad and make note of it so I can learn and be a better director. The worst singers are the best teachers - they teach you what not to do. It is fun to analyze their flaws. I don’t know, if a child gifted you a picture they drew and it was awful, wouldn’t it touch your heart and you would appreciate the gift that it is and the effort that went into its creation? I kind of see bad singing like that. I am also gifted with a very low attention span. For instance, when I was nine I

I’m thinking: “PLEASE STOP!!! PLEASE!!! TURN IT OFF!!! AAAAAAUGH!!! OH, THE HUMANITY!!!”  I’m usually much too polite to actually confront the person about the terrible singing. If it persists, I usually end up leaving the area to escape it. Or, if I have my iPhone and earbuds with me, I’ll turn up some really loud music (something with a consistently loud volume level) to drown out the sound of the tone-deaf singer.

Well, before music school, I would think, “Well. You’re doing better than I could do.” Unless it was just exceptionally bad, and then I’d think, “Well. You tried. Good game.” And then I’d try to blot out the sound. Now that I have taken some music classes and know more about singing, and more importantly, a better sense of pitch, I still think the same things, but now my first reaction, before those, is, “Wait, wait, you’re singing that note flat. Nope. Sharp. Little higher. Open your mouth more. Flat…” Curse you, four semesters of Sight-Screaming!

I know a guy who is tone deaf, his hearing is shot. Technically his singing is awful, with very poor relative pitch sense. Yet he ‘sings’ very amusing and engaging songs that entertain all his friends. He knows and we know that, strictly speaking, he is a very bad singer. But he has found a repertoire that gives us all much pleasure. Otherwise I would politely applaud and find reasons to be out of earshot!

First I say to my self, wow, that note was really flat, that vowel was wrong, they didn’t harmonize correctly, the flute went sharp. I name a lot of little nit picky things that combine to make a terrible experience, if the ending note/chord doesn’t lock, that is an unforgivable sin. But I still clap, albeit out of politeness, not enjoyment.
